questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department for acute pain in the left eye. He reports having awoken in the morning with a foreign body sensation. He had forgotten to remove his contact lenses before going to sleep. After removing the contact lenses, he experienced immediate pain, discomfort, and watering of the left eye. He reports that the foreign body sensation persists and that rinsing with water has not improved the pain. He has been wearing contact lenses for 4 years and occasionally forgets to remove them at night. He has no history of serious medical illness. On examination, the patient appears distressed with pain and photophobia in the left eye. Administration of a topical anesthetic relieves the pain. Visual acuity is 20/30 in both eyes. Ocular motility and pupillary response are normal. Corneal reflex is normal and symmetric in both eyes. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Fluorescein examination is the test of choice for identifying a corneal abrasion. Corneal abrasions are defects in the corneal epithelium that often occur secondary to corneal trauma. Removal of contact lenses after wearing them overnight is likely to have caused a corneal abrasion in this patient. Fluorescein dye specifically stains the epithelial defects, making them easily identifiable on slit lamp, ophthalmoscopic, or Wood lamp examination. In addition, the conjunctival surface of the eyelids should be examined to rule out a foreign body such as a retained contact lens. In corneal abrasion, photophobia can be attributed to spastic miosis resulting from the trigeminal sensation of the cornea.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography of the left eye with fluorescein staining

A small area of green staining (black arrow) confirms a corneal abrasion. Significant conjunctival injection is also visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Ocular ultrasonography can visualize structures in the back of the eye, especially when examination of the fundus cannot be performed due to opacities in the anterior segment (e.g., bacterial keratitis, dense cataracts), which is, however, not the case here. Abnormalities that can be detected on ultrasound include retinal detachments and vitreous hemorrhage. This patient does not complain of flashes of light, floaters, or sudden loss of vision to suggest any of these pathologies.

C) INCORRECT:

Gonioscopy is useful in diagnosing acute angle closure glaucoma. Patients would typically present with severe ocular pain that does not resolve on the application of a topical anesthetic. Examination would show a mid-fixed dilated pupil and conjunctival injection. As this patient has a normal pupillary exam and ocular pain that resolved with the administration of an anesthetic, glaucoma is an unlikely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the orbit is used to evaluate for an intraocular foreign body and/or an open globe injury. While patients with an intraocular foreign body or an open globe injury typically present with pain, decreased visual acuity of the affected eye, not both eyes, is also expected. Patients with an open globe injury usually have additional findings of an irregular pupil and a relative afferent pupillary defect. In addition, this patient has no history to suggest blunt or penetrating ocular trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Ocular discharge cultures may be useful in patients with acute bacterial conjunctivitis or bacterial keratitis. Both of these conditions can occur in contact lens wearers secondary to inadequate contact lens hygiene. Bacterial conjunctivitis and keratitis manifest with tearing and foreign body sensation. However, severe purulent discharge and conjunctival injection are also seen in bacterial conjunctivitis. In keratitis, the visual acuity of the affected eye is decreased and, if severe, corneal edema and hypopyon would be present.
Image Description:

Left eye

There is massive conjunctival injection (hyperemia) and purulent discharge, especially visible in the medial corner of the eye and the margin of the lower lid.

This is the characteristic appearance of bacterial conjunctivitis.
questions.hint: Eye pain, excessive tearing, photophobia, and foreign body sensation that appear acutely after the removal of an overworn contact lens are suggestive of a corneal abrasion. Although visual acuity is preserved in corneal abrasion, this patient has a previous history of wearing contact lenses and decreased visual acuity in both eyes, suggesting a refractive error.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man presents with decreased vision, pain, and photophobia after his 8-month-old son poked him in the left eye with his finger. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/100 in the left eye. Although the cornea looks clear on penlight examination, fluorescein staining shows a discrete area of uptake in the left eye when examined with a cobalt-blue light (figure). The conjunctiva of the left eye is injected. The patient’s pain is relieved when numbing drops are administered for the examination.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pressure patching in a corneal abrasion that could contain Pseudomonas is contraindicated because it could create an environment that promotes bacterial growth.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical anesthetics should not be used to treat a corneal abrasion. Patients with corneal abrasions usually feel complete pain relief when anesthetic drops are instilled into the eye for the examination, but a patient should never be given a bottle of anesthetic drops or a prescription for them, because repeated use can cause corneal melting, leading to blindness. Pain management for patients with corneal abrasions can include lubricating ointment and oral analgesic medications.

C) INCORRECT:

Bandage contact lenses should not be used as the sole treatment for corneal abrasions and require ophthalmologist care if used.

D) INCORRECT:

Prednisolone drops are not used for corneal abrasions and can increase the risk of infection.

E) CORRECT:

A corneal abrasion can be suspected based on a clinical history of trauma and confirmed with evidence of an epithelial defect on fluorescein staining. In patients who have a corneal abrasion from a fingernail, a piece of vegetable matter, or a contact lens, the most appropriate treatment is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers Pseudomonas species. A fluoroquinolone such as ofloxacin is an appropriate choice.

Key learning point: A corneal abrasion caused by a fingernail should be treated with a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers Pseudomonas species.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man reports a 24-hour history of purulent discharge, pain, and decreased vision in his right eye (figure). He wears contact lenses and occasionally sleeps with them in place.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A chalazion is associated with a swollen eyelid and mucus discharge.

B) INCORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis (pinkeye) is associated with a clear cornea, watery discharge, conjunctival injection, and lid crusting upon awakening. It can progress from one eye to the other and is often preceded by an upper respiratory illness.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute angle-closure glaucoma is associated with eye pain, redness, photophobia, headache, and decreased vision. The cornea may show diffuse haze, but there is no focal infiltrate or opacity. The pupil is mid-dilated and minimally reactive.

D) INCORRECT:

Uveitis is characterized by injection, photophobia, decreased vision, intraocular inflammation, and a clear cornea.

E) CORRECT:

Pain, photophobia, and decreased vision are common symptoms of corneal ulcers. On examination, patients with such ulcers generally have an injected eye, corneal opacities, and hypopyon (a layer of leukocytes in the anterior chamber), all of which are shown in the figure. Patients also generally have mucus discharge. Risk factors include overuse of contact lenses, corneal abrasions, eye trauma, eye surgery, corneal laser surgery, and gonococcal conjunctivitis.

A corneal ulcer is an ophthalmologic emergency; if left untreated, it can lead to vision loss and blindness. The treatment regimen includes topical antimicrobials, cycloplegic eyedrops for pain management, and daily eye examinations. Topical numbing medications such as proparacaine should never be prescribed to a patient with a corneal ulcer, as they can lead to corneal melting and worsening of the corneal ulcer.

Key learning point: The most likely explanation for purulent discharge, pain, and decreased vision in the eye of a contact-lens wearer whose examination shows an injected eye, corneal opacities, and hypopyon is corneal ulcer.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents with a one-hour history of foreign-body sensation, pain, photophobia, and decreased vision in the right eye. She states that she was hedging a bush with clippers when she felt something strike her eye. She was not wearing safety glasses at the time of the injury. She has no history of ocular disease and does not wear contact lenses.
On examination, she has 20/100 vision in the right eye and 20/20 vision in the left eye. Extraocular movements on the right are full without proptosis. Eversion of the right eyelid reveals no evidence of a foreign body. Penlight examination of the right eye reveals injection of the conjunctiva, irregular corneal light reflex, normal pupil reaction, and a bright red reflex. Slit-lamp examination of the right eye reveals central corneal uptake of fluorescein stain. The left eye is normal.
In addition to scheduling an ophthalmologic follow-up, what is the most appropriate next step in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Patch the right eye and apply bacitracin ointment

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Orbital imaging is not recommended unless there is suspicion of an intraocular or orbital foreign body. In this case, neither the history nor the examination findings suggests these conditions.

B) INCORRECT:

Patching the eye after a nonsterile abrasion is not recommended, given the increased risk for corneal infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids should never be used because this could lead to bacterial overgrowth and increased intraocular pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Proparacaine, a topical anesthetic, should be used only to facilitate a thorough eye examination in a clinical setting. Home use should never be permitted because these drops are associated with an increased risk of corneal decompensation, ulcer formation, and perforation. Pain management can include topical ophthalmic lubricants and oral analgesic medications.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and clinical history are suggestive of a corneal abrasion or possibly a superficial foreign body. Her symptoms of pain, photophobia, and decreased vision suggest corneal involvement, and fluorescein staining confirms the presence of a corneal abrasion.

When the suspected corneal injury is caused by organic matter (a hedge branch in this case), the range of potential pathogens is broader than with nonorganic matter, and a fluoroquinolone eyedrop should be prescribed. If the corneal injury is associated with nonorganic matter, then erythromycin or bacitracin ophthalmic ointment is an acceptable alternative. Patients with corneal injury should follow up with an ophthalmologist as soon as possible for a thorough ophthalmic examination.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a corneal abrasion caused by a tree branch is fluoroquinolone eyedrops.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, osteoporosis, and obstructive sleep apnea (treated with continuous positive airway pressure) is admitted for pneumonia. During her hospitalization, she reports pain in her right eye, a foreign-body sensation, and decreased vision.
She has 20/30 vision in her left eye and 20/100 vision in her right eye. A penlight examination reveals an injected right eye, a white spot on the cornea, and a hypopyon (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corneal abrasions produce symptoms similar to those of corneal ulcers, but the cornea is clear without infiltrates or opacities.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute angle-closure glaucoma is characterized by a hazy cornea, a fixed dilated pupil, injection, and eye pain.

C) CORRECT:

Corneal ulcers are associated with conjunctival injection, decreased vision, ocular pain, and a corneal defect that appears white on examination. A hypopyon (layering of white cells in the anterior chamber of the eye) may be present with more severe infections. Risk factors include advancing age, incomplete lid closure, contact lens wear, and excessive corneal exposure to air (as may occur in patients being treated with continuous positive airway pressure). The ulcer should be cultured, if possible; broad-spectrum antibiotic eyedrops should be initiated; and the patient should be followed closely by an ophthalmologist.

Key learning point: A patient who presents with eye pain, decreased vision, injection, and a white spot on the cornea most likely has a corneal ulcer.

D) INCORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis is associated with ocular discharge and injection but is typically bilateral and is not associated with large corneal opacities.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior uveitis is characterized by severe photophobia, ocular injection and a clear cornea.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old-boy with a sulfa allergy is brought to the clinic with tearing and redness in his right eye. He said his eye started hurting after his younger brother accidentally poked him with a toy fire truck. He finds it difficult to open his eye and feels like something is stuck in it. He has not had any recent nasal congestion or cough.
On examination, the child is holding his right eye shut, and there is tearing. There is mild injection to the sclera. The pupils are reactive to light, and extraocular movements are intact.
After fluorescein staining of the right eye, a 4-mm, ragged, circular defect is illuminated on the cornea (figure). Inversion of the eyelid reveals no obvious foreign body.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Apply 0.5% erythromycin ointment to the affected eye four times daily
Apply 1% prednisone ophthalmic solution to the affected eye four times daily
Recommend urgent referral to an ophthalmologist
Place a patch over the affected eye for the next 48 hours
Administer 10% sulfacetamide sodium ophthalmic solution to the affected eye four times daily

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A corneal abrasion is a defect in the epithelial surface of the cornea, commonly resulting from trauma. Fluorescein staining can detect a corneal abrasion by binding to exposed basement membrane; when illuminated with cobalt blue light, the defect appears green. This patient's corneal abrasion is small, covering less than a quarter of the corneal surface.

Treatment of a corneal abrasion is focused on relieving pain, preventing bacterial superinfection, and increasing the speed of healing. Topical erythromycin is used to prevent bacterial superinfection in uncomplicated corneal abrasions. An ointment is preferred over drops because, theoretically, it can also function as a lubricant for the eye.

Evidence has shown that simple corneal abrasions do not require patching. There is no evidence that patching speeds recovery.

Uncomplicated corneal abrasions heal within 24 to 48 hours and do not require ophthalmologic referral unless there is a penetrating eye injury, chemical burn, corneal ulcer, hyphema or hypopyon, or retained foreign body.

Key learning point: The management of corneal abrasions includes the removal of any foreign body, pain control, and topical antibiotic ointment.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid eye drops are not indicated because they can have a negative effect on healing and may increase the risk of secondary infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Uncomplicated corneal abrasions heal within 24 to 48 hours and do not require ophthalmologic referral unless there is a penetrating eye injury, chemical burn, corneal ulcer, hyphema or hypopyon, or retained foreign body.

D) INCORRECT:

Evidence has shown that simple corneal abrasions do not require patching. There is no evidence that patching speeds recovery.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with sulfa allergy, sulfacetamide solution would not be appropriate because of the potential allergic reaction.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy presents with left eye pain, profuse tearing, and photophobia after playing outside. He was running very close to the bushes in the backyard when he suddenly stopped, grabbed his eye, and started crying.
The boy cannot open his left eye voluntarily and is rocking back and forth because of the pain. There is clear drainage leaking from the affected eye. There is a linear scratch from the inferior aspect of the lower lid obliquely across the cheek. The lids are carefully opened, and the pupil on the left is noted to be round and constricted. Examination of the lids, lashes, globe, and lacrimal duct area does not show any evidence of penetrating trauma. The anterior chamber appears clear.
After use of a topical anesthetic, the child is found to have a visual acuity of 20/20 in both eyes and a normal red reflex.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe a 3-day course of proparacaine drops
Irrigate the eye with saline, and prescribe ofloxacin eye drops
Provide an eye patch, and schedule reevaluation in 3 days
Examine the eye after instillation of topical fluorescein dye

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Proparacaine, a topical anesthetic, should be used only to facilitate a thorough eye examination in a clinical setting. Home use should never be permitted. When used long-term, these drops are toxic to the cornea and are associated with an increased risk of corneal decompensation, ulcer formation, and perforation.

B) INCORRECT:

After fluorescein examination, the eyelid should be inverted to evaluate for foreign bodies. If a foreign body is found, saline irrigation may be attempted, but it is not the first step in evaluation. Further management may include topical antibiotic ointment but only after the diagnosis of corneal abrasion has been confirmed and the presence of foreign bodies is excluded.

C) INCORRECT:

This child most likely suffered a corneal abrasion from a branch but the diagnosis should be confirmed with a fluorescein dye examination. Ultimately, referral to an ophthalmologist is indicated if there is concern for penetrating eye injury, corneal ulcer, retained foreign body, or significant injury to the lids or lacrimal ducts.

D) INCORRECT:

Orbital radiographs can be helpful to diagnose a metallic foreign body, but this patient's history is not suggestive of a metallic foreign body, and a careful examination is the best next step in evaluation.

E) CORRECT:

This child most likely suffered a corneal abrasion from a branch. The diagnosis should be confirmed with a fluorescein dye examination, which involves lightly touching a fluorescein strip to the conjunctiva. The dye spreads over the cornea and stains any exposed basement membrane of the epithelium; when illuminated with cobalt blue light, the defect will appear green.

After fluorescein examination, the eyelid should be inverted to evaluate for foreign bodies.

After the diagnosis of corneal abrasion has been confirmed and the presence of foreign bodies is excluded, further management may include topical antibiotic ointment. Evidence regarding the use of antibiotics after uncomplicated corneal abrasions is lacking, but in practice, antibiotic ointment is often prescribed because it provides symptomatic relief and may help to prevent secondary bacterial infection. Ultimately, referral to an ophthalmologist is indicated if there is concern for penetrating eye injury, chemical burn, corneal ulcer, hyphema, retained foreign body, or significant injury to the lids or lacrimal ducts.

Key learning point: The most appropriate strategy to evaluate for corneal abrasion is to examine the eye after instilling some drops of fluorescein dye.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man reports a 24-hour history of purulent discharge, pain, and decreased vision in his right eye. He wears contact lenses and occasionally sleeps with them in place. A photograph of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:

A chalazion is associated with a swollen eyelid and mucus discharge.

B) INCORRECT:

C) INCORRECT:

D) INCORRECT:

Uveitis is characterized by injection, photophobia, decreased vision, intraocular inflammation, and a clear cornea.

E) CORRECT:

Pain, photophobia, and decreased vision are common symptoms of corneal ulcers. On examination, patients with such ulcers generally have an injected eye, corneal opacities, and hypopyon (a layer of leukocytes in the anterior chamber), all of which are shown in the photograph. Patients also generally have mucus discharge. Risk factors include overuse of contact lenses, corneal abrasions, eye trauma, eye surgery, corneal laser surgery, and gonococcal conjunctivitis.

Topical numbing medications such as proparacaine should never be prescribed to a patient with a corneal ulcer, as they can lead to corneal melting and worsening of the corneal ulcer.

Key learning point: The most likely explanation for purulent discharge, pain, and decreased vision in the eye of a contact-lens wearer whose examination shows an injected eye, corneal opacities, and hypopyon is corneal ulcer.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the office because of decreased vision, pain, and photophobia after his 8-month-old son poked him in the left eye with his finger. Slit lamp examination with fluorescein staining shows a small area with green staining on the left eye when examined with a cobalt-blue light. The conjunctiva of the left eye is injected. The patient’s pain is relieved when numbing drops are administered for the examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pressure patching in a corneal abrasion that could contain Pseudomonas is contraindicated because it could create an environment that promotes bacterial growth.

C) INCORRECT:

D) INCORRECT:

Prednisolone drops are not used for corneal abrasions and can increase the risk of infection.

E) CORRECT:

In patients who have a corneal abrasion from a fingernail, a piece of vegetable matter, or a contact lens, the most appropriate treatment is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers Pseudomonas species. A fluoroquinolone such as ofloxacin is an appropriate choice.

Key learning point: A corneal abrasion caused by a fingernail should be treated with a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers Pseudomonas species.
Image Description:

Corneal abrasion on fluorescein staining
questions.hint: Blurry vision, eye pain, and photophobia after direct injury (e.g., being poked in the eye) and evidence of an epithelial defect on fluorescein staining are suggestive of a corneal abrasion.

D) CORRECT:

In patients who have a corneal abrasion from a fingernail, a piece of vegetable matter, or a contact lens, the most appropriate treatment is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers Pseudomonas species. A fluoroquinolone such as ofloxacin is an appropriate choice.

Key learning point: A corneal abrasion caused by a fingernail should be treated with a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers Pseudomonas species.
Image Description:

Corneal abrasion on fluorescein staining

E) INCORRECT:

Pressure patching in a corneal abrasion that could contain Pseudomonas is contraindicated because it could create an environment that promotes bacterial growth.
questions.hint: Blurry vision, eye pain, and photophobia after direct injury (e.g., being poked in the eye) and evidence of an epithelial defect on fluorescein staining are suggestive of a corneal abrasion.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient presents with right eye pain and foreign body sensation after removing a contact lens 4 hours ago. The patient reports difficulty opening the eye and mild photophobia. Visual acuity is 20/25 in the affected eye. Slit lamp examination with fluorescein staining shows a 2-mm round central corneal defect with smooth edges. No foreign body is visible, and the anterior chamber is clear. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Topical ciprofloxacin and urgent opthamology follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This would not be appropriate management, since contact lens-related corneal abrasions require prophylactic antibiotic therapy due to increased risk for bacterial keratitis, particularly from Pseudomonas species.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin is appropriate for traumatic or potentially contaminated abrasions but does not have the antipseudomonal activity required to treat contact lens-related abrasions.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- The smooth, round central defect is characteristic of contact lens-related abrasions. Contact lens wearers with an abrasion require antibiotics with antipseudomonal activity, such as ciprofloxacin, due to an increased risk of Pseudomonas keratitis. All patients require ophthalmology follow-up, ideally within 24 hours, regardless of the size of the lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

The use of at-home topical anesthetics for corneal abrasions is controversial. The American College of Physicians affirms the safety of at-home topical anesthetics for simple corneal abrasions but recommends limiting the duration to less than 24 hours. The FDA does not approve prescribing topical anesthetics for home use due to the risk of corneal toxicity with prolonged use. This patient requires antibiotic therapy, making another option more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Eye patches are contraindicated in corneal abrasions because they have not been shown to improve pain and can delay healing. Oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are preferred over acetaminophen for corneal pain management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old construction worker presents with acute left eye pain and photophobia after grinding metal 2 hours ago. The patient has normal visual acuity. On gross examination, there is conjunctival injection and copious tearing. Slit lamp examination with fluorescein staining shows a small corneal defect, no visible foreign body, and no signs of anterior chamber involvement. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Evert the upper eyelid and re-examine
Administer topical anesthetic and irrigate with saline

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate ophthalmology consultation is indicated for suspected open globe injury, foreign bodies that cannot be removed, and/or foreign bodies that are so large or deeply embedded they affect central vision. This patient's presentation does not meet the criteria for urgent consultation at this stage of evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the orbits is indicated if there is a suspected intraocular foreign body. However, this patient has normal visual acuity and no signs of anterior chamber involvement, making intraocular foreign body unlikely. A CT scan is not the most appropriate next step for a suspected superficial foreign body.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Eversion of the upper eyelid is the most appropriate next step. This maneuver is crucial for inspecting the palpebral conjunctiva, a common location for retained foreign bodies, especially when a corneal abrasion is present and no foreign body is visible on the cornea. Given this patient's history of grinding metal, a small particle could easily be lodged under the eyelid, causing the symptoms and the corneal defect.

D) INCORRECT:

Orbital ultrasound is an alternative imaging modality for suspected penetrating injury when clinical examination is inconclusive. This patient's presentation suggests a superficial rather than penetrating injury, making an alternative initial step more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical anesthetic and irrigation will be required in this patient, but the presence of a corneal defect with no visible foreign body requires a thorough examination to locate potential retained material first.

questions.text: A 35-year-old welder presents to the emergency department 2 hours after a metal shaving struck his left eye while he was grinding without protective eyewear. He reports severe eye pain, photophobia, and blurred vision. Examination shows conjunctival injection and epiphora. Slit lamp examination with fluorescein staining shows a 3-mm linear corneal defect that does not extend through the full thickness of the cornea. The anterior chamber depth appears normal, the pupil is round and reactive, and no foreign body is visualized. What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Topical antibiotics and discharge with 24-hour follow-up
Eye patching and oral analgesics for 48 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The need for surgical repair is determined by an ophthalmologist. Small superficial corneal lacerations can be managed conservatively, with surgical repair reserved for deeper or more extensive lesions.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Corneal lacerations require urgent ophthalmology consult regardless of depth or size. Small, superficial lesions can be managed conservatively with analgesia and prophylactic topical antibiotics depending on risk factors (e.g., contact lens use). Deep or extensive lesions may require surgical repair.

C) INCORRECT:

While topical antibiotics may be used as part of conservative management, an additional step in management is required for corneal lacerations.

D) INCORRECT:

Eye patches should be avoided in corneal injuries as they have not been shown to alleviate pain and can delay healing. Additionally, corneal lacerations require an urgent ophthalmology consult before management is initiated.

E) INCORRECT:

While topical corticosteroids and cycloplegic agents may be used to treat uveitis, they are not used to manage corneal lacerations.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the ED with severe left eye pain, redness, and blurred vision for 2 days. She wears soft contact lenses and admits to occasionally sleeping in them. Vital signs are normal. Ocular examination reveals conjunctival injection, a corneal epithelial defect with a white infiltrate, and purulent discharge. Visual acuity is reduced in the affected eye. Fluorescein staining demonstrates uptake at the lesion. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir may be indicated for herpetic keratitis, which may present with a dendritic ulcer on fluorescein staining. This patient has a corneal ulcer with stromal infiltration and purulent discharge, suggesting bacterial infection, not herpes simplex virus.

B) CORRECT:

Correct — Bacterial corneal ulcers, especially in contact lens users, require immediate broad-spectrum topical antibiotics, most commonly fluoroquinolones, to prevent rapid progression and potential vision loss. Delay in treatment can result in corneal perforation and permanent scarring.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids should be avoided initially in suspected bacterial corneal ulcers until appropriate antibiotic therapy is established and pathogen identification is confirmed, as they may be beneficial but require specialist oversight.

D) INCORRECT:

Artificial tears may relieve discomfort in minor superficial keratitis or dry eye but are insufficient for a true corneal ulcer. This condition requires urgent antimicrobial therapy to prevent irreversible vision loss.

E) INCORRECT:

V vancomycin is not indicated for corneal ulcers, which require topical antibiotic therapy to achieve adequate corneal penetration and directly target the infection at the corneal surface. Systemic antibiotics have poor corneal penetration and are not first-line therapy for bacterial keratitis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old construction worker presents to the ED with right eye pain, tearing, and photophobia after working without protective eyewear. Vital signs are normal. On examination, the right conjunctiva is injected, and a metallic foreign body is embedded in the superficial cornea. Visual acuity is 20/25 in the left eye and 20/40 in the right eye. Fluorescein staining shows no Seidel sign. Copious saline irrigation is performed, but the foreign body remains. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Immediate ophthalmology consultation for surgical removal
Removal with a sterile needle or eye spud, followed by topical antibiotics
Topical corticosteroid drops to reduce inflammation
Discharge with lubricating drops and reassurance only
Topical anesthetics and CT of the orbits

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deep or penetrating corneal foreign bodies require urgent ophthalmology involvement. However, this patient has a superficial metallic foreign body without evidence of perforation, which can be managed safely in the ED.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Superficial corneal foreign bodies can be carefully removed using a sterile needle or spud under slit-lamp visualization. The proper technique involves holding the instrument tangential to the cornea and using a scooping or picking motion to lift the foreign body. This approach minimizes the risk of deeper corneal penetration while effectively removing the debris from the corneal surface. After removal, topical antibiotic drops or ointment should be considered to prevent secondary infection, and ophthalmology follow-up should be arranged.

C) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic management with corticosteroid drops only is not appropriate for a patient with a corneal foreign body, which necessitates immediate removal.

D) INCORRECT:

Lubricating drops may provide symptomatic relief but are insufficient management for a retained corneal foreign body. The risk of infection and scarring necessitates removal.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical anesthetics may be used during examination and procedures, but orbital CT is reserved for suspected intraocular foreign bodies or when penetrating injury cannot be ruled out clinically. This patient has a clearly visible superficial corneal foreign body without evidence of globe penetration.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic with a 1-day history of severe right eye pain, photophobia, and a foreign body sensation. He reports blurry vision in that eye. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and a hazy, white infiltrate on the cornea that stains with fluorescein. Which of the following is the most likely risk factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A recent upper respiratory infection is a common preceding event for viral conjunctivitis, which can sometimes lead to corneal involvement. However, adenoviral keratitis typically causes multiple small, subepithelial infiltrates without a large overlying defect. Herpes simplex keratitis, another possibility, classically manifests with a dendritic ulcer, which is not described here.

B) CORRECT:

Contact lens wear, particularly improper use such as sleeping in them or poor hygiene, is the single most important risk factor. This practice creates a hypoxic environment, facilitates microbial adhesion to the lens, and can cause microabrasions on the corneal surface, allowing bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa to invade.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with ocular conditions such as peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUK), which involves corneal inflammation and thinning. While PUK can manifest with pain and an infiltrate, it is typically located at the corneal periphery and is an autoimmune process, not primarily infectious. This patient's presentation is more consistent with a central infectious process, and he has no other signs of systemic autoimmune disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Ocular trauma can cause a corneal abrasion, which disrupts the epithelial barrier and creates a portal of entry for bacteria, leading to infectious keratitis. However, this patient does not report any specific traumatic event.

E) INCORRECT:

Exposure to contaminated water, such as in swimming pools, is a primary risk factor for Acanthamoeba keratitis. Although this condition causes severe eye pain and a corneal infiltrate, it is much rarer than bacterial keratitis. Furthermore, the clinical course is often more subacute, and a usually involves a characteristic ring infiltrate, which is not seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's severe right eye pain, photophobia, foreign body sensation, and physical examination results showing a corneal infiltrate with an overlying epithelial defect are consistent with infectious keratitis.
